column2: Text
RT @James_Breakwell : https://t.co/xXNqUAmZqK

I almost never make fun of specific people, but this guy deserved it.
https://t.co/Dr1Pz7Zw3n

My 10-year-old told my 6-year-old she couldn't play with her.

My 6-year-old got mad and grabbed a pencil and a piece of paper.

I was going to congratulate her on not choosing violence, but this is worse. https://t.co/yXlAPKY1RU

8-year-old: I'm ready for anything.

Me: You're not even dressed.

8: Well, I'm not ready for that.

Everything you think you know about being in love is wrong.
https://t.co/LoAqQqeggq
This is the good news you needed today. https://t.co/Dr1Pz7Zw3n

8-year-old: I wish I was a dog. They can do whatever they want.

Me: They can't eat doughnuts.

8: I don't want to be a dog.

My father-in-law let my 12-year-old color his hair with hair chalk.

Being a grandpa is harder than it looks. https://t.co/XufYU0XtjR

10-year-old: I don't need socks any more.

Me: What about when your feet get cold?

10: We can turn up the heat.

Here's my newsletter from last week. It was the most incredible night of my life, and it's definitely never going to happen again.
https://t.co/8K6ei0Qpp4

I usually just guess, but today, I'll try science. Which email subject line are you more likely to click on?

"You're Better Than Him"

Or

"You're Better Than An Elector-Archbishop"

I taught my 10-year-old how to play a new card game.

I took it easy on her and lost by a little.

Then I played my best to teach her a lesson.

That's when I lost by a lot.

12-year-old: Did you win the big lottery?

Me: I was close. I only missed six numbers.

12: How many numbers were there?

Me: Six.

I made a new rule at dinner tonight.

Every time my kids complained about my cooking, I gave them an extra helping.

It was the quietest meal we've had in months.

6-year-old: The strawberries went bad.

Me: Throw them out.

6: I already ate them all.

The plot thickens.

My wife and I went to Europe while our kids went to Grandma’s house.

Every time we sent them a picture of the amazing things we were seeing, my 12-year-old sent back a picture of a puzzle she put together.

I'm still not sure if she was being sarcastic. https://t.co/gBjlMzsMnI
We're at the guinea pig stacking portion of summer break. https://t.co/MnM4HveI4x

For this week's bonus newsletter for paid subscribers, I tell the story of how an entire city became my enemy.
https://t.co/1f7Fny9YXF

My kids absolutely, positively do not want to go back to school.

They're also currently playing school for the millionth time this summer.

Children are complicated.

Me: Don't do that. You'll get hurt.

My kids: *do that* *get hurt*

Me: Well?

My kids: Why didn't you warn us?

6-year-old: Is there a video of your wedding?

Me: No. We didn't want one.

6: Was Mom embarrassed?

Me: Want to have a picnic?

8-year-old: Can we have it inside?

Me: That's just a regular lunch.

8: You can put a blanket on the table.

6-year-old: I just saw the most amazing YouTube video!

Me: What was it about?

6: I forget. Let's watch it again.

My wife and I went waaay outside our comfort zone, and it ended up being one of the best nights of our lives.
https://t.co/RgVGRzLYMo

[kids yell at each other]

Me: What are you playing?

8-year-old: Ninjas.

Me: Ninjas are quiet.

8: Not when they're sisters.
She plopped down in the hall between the dining room and kitchen, waiting to see if anyone would drop food. A pig is patient. https://t.co/3LKb0cLnbA

This was the night my wife and I peaked. It's all downhill from here.
https://t.co/8K6ei0Qpp4

A hose under our bathroom sink randomly disconnected, spraying water everywhere.

My wife heard it from the next room and stopped it within seconds, saving us thousands of dollars in damages.

Not all heroes wear caps, but they can all find the water shut off valve.

10-year-old: I can't figure out the controls for this game.

Me: Did you do the tutorial?

10: I'm not a nerd.

12-year-old: I'm actually kind of looking forward to school.

Me: Good. It starts in two weeks.

12: No! I didn't mean it!
Saturday status: Why is the rum gone? https://t.co/VTOg1KTub1
@PetoskyTurtle Then your were playing correctly.

I paid $30 on Ebay for a game I played with my mom for an entire afternoon in 1997 when I was twelve.

And you know what? It holds up.

To everyone who said I had to grow up: You were wrong. https://t.co/L4Ai50zCBB

My father-in-law is watching my kids this weekend.

He didn't do it for nothing.

In exchange, he demanded that I give him my van so he could wash and detail it.

He drives a hard bargain.
@ambernoelle I have four kids and my oldest, 12, asks me this every day. Including when we've both both home together all day.
My mom tried to get some nice pictures of the girls. If you splice all four together, it sort of worked. https://t.co/ykXk9kwL6S

A parenting monologue I have at least a thousand times a day:

"Girls, what are you doing? Actually, don't tell me. Just stop."
We're at the "paper finger claws" stage of summer boredom. https://t.co/xdqOmeyT1R

8-year-old: *interrupting me* Dad.

Me: What?

8: I would never wear stormtrooper armor. It doesn't even stop blaster fire.

Good to know.

This is my weekly bonus article for paid subscribers, but the free preview portion is definitely long enough to let you know if you'll care about the ending.
https://t.co/BngYTvbuya

This is way overdue, but it's finally done.
https://t.co/G4FTmaIlyd

My kids spent two hours "cleaning" and accomplished literally nothing.

Then I told them they had ten minutes to pick up everything or they were grounded.

Then they finished in eight.

A neighbor called me at work to let me know one of my pet pigs escaped.

I frantically called my kids at home to tell them to get her.

But my kids checked, and both of our pigs are still in our yard. Somebody else has a pig who escaped.

We're a bad influence on this town.

My kids left a toy broom, dust pan, and mop on the floor.

I'm impressed.

They managed to make a real mess while pretending to clean up a fake one.

Me: Oh no. A meteor damaged the James Webb telescope.

6-year-old: Yeah. I saw three fire trucks go by.

I traveled 4,000 miles to write this post.
https://t.co/7lKVNxawew

6-year-old: That's an unlucky penny.

Me: What makes it unlucky?

6: My sister found it instead of me.

Me: We need to clean the house today.

10-year-old: Why?

Me: So it's not dirty anymore.

10: That's not a very good reason.

My kids spent a week with my mom and she said they were angels the whole time.

I picked them up this morning and they've done nothing but fight ever since.

Apparently my mom lied so I would take them back.

I got a text from the school reminding me to enroll my kids for the fall.

That was unexpected.

I'm honestly surprised the school wants them back.

I just got back from Europe, and I have some thoughts. Surely this won't be controversial at all.
https://t.co/7lKVNxawew
Flight update: Instead of separating us by 20 rows, the airline decided my wife and I could sit together because love conquers all and also there is no escape.
The airline seated me twenty rows from my wife for an eight hour flight and I'm honestly not sure if they're trying to do me a solid or ruin my life.

Wife: Did you post that picture of us?

Me: Yeah.

Wife: Before I looked at it?

Me: *deletes the post*

I'm currently four thousand miles from my kids.

My 12-year-old sent me a text.

She wasn't curious about what I was up to.

She just wanted me to use my parental controls to let her download an app.

Love you, too, kid.

Glass 1: I am a sophisticated drinker.

Glass 6: I am a grape. https://t.co/EFishfbLkW

[tasting wine at a French vineyard after the vineyard guy gave an hour long lecture on how to evaluate six separate flavor metrics]

Wife: What does it taste like?

Me: Wine.
The only reason to be on a boat is to drink too much and then take turns posing ironically for overly dramatic photos. https://t.co/MH06k7lBnF

RT @jhnrbry : "Human beings have an insatiable desire to belong. That's a major conflict for those of us who also have an insatiable desire to be left the hell alone. It’s the introvert’s dilemma: We want to be by ourselves, but only sort of." @XplodingUnicorn capturing introverts perfectly.

I called my mom to ask her how things were going watching my kids.

All she said was, "Loud."

At least I think that's what she said. I couldn't really hear her over all the screaming.

"I love your dress."

"It has pockets!"

—The conversation my wife has had with literally every single woman on this cruise

My wife and I were last ones awake on the cruise.

At last call, we grabbed more drinks and headed to the top deck in the dark.

I've taken pictures of palaces and castles, but these terrible selfies are the best of the whole trip.

You can't see our faces.

You can see our joy. https://t.co/YjBzE2GwiV
RT @James_Breakwell : https://t.co/Z0bwzmFuVS

The last bullet point is legitimately the best advice I have and also the only real advice I'll ever give.
https://t.co/6p3EY5prkn
Confession time: The only reason I took this picture of my wife was so I could tell her to say cheese. https://t.co/CgGILWW6w4

I shared a table on a cruise with a seemingly normal retired dude. Turns out he was a two star general who spent 15 years as a fighter pilot. Oh, and he was in the Pentagon on September 11th.

Then he asked me what I do for a living. I told him I couldn't remember.

Wife: Oh no. You ruined that picture.

Me: How?

Wife: You were in it.

Are you officially old yet? These are the eight sure ways to tell.
https://t.co/6p3EY57QsP
I'm on a river cruise and this is the first thing I saw when I looked out my window this morning. I guess they're expecting some rain today. https://t.co/STm34oopJV
Fun fact: We lack the maturity to survive an actual boat emergency. https://t.co/xRANMaxV85

Wife: It's a wine and cheese TASTING.

Me: What's your point?

Wife: You're supposed to taste it, not inhale it.

Me: My tongue just slows me down.

That awkward moment when you fall asleep in Newark and wake up in Amsterdam. Also, my wife wants you to know that I'm terrible at selfies but we both look like perfectly normal people in real life. https://t.co/x439rabZxx

My 10-year-old carefully packed everything she'd need for a week-long trip to Grandma's house.

Then she forgot her entire bag in her room.

Guess who got a shopping spree for all new clothes.

I'm pretty sure she planned this.

In case you missed it, here's the big news from yesterday.
https://t.co/yaeixpFCQ5

Me: You sound a little hoarse.

Wife: Just call me Little Sebastion.

Me: If I could, I'd marry you again.

My wife asked me to open her nail polish bottle.

I felt pretty buff when I got the lid off.

All it took was a rubber jar opener and a pair of vise grips.

So I have some news.
https://t.co/yaeixpFCQ5

When I was just outside the room, someone shouted, "DAD'S COMING," and all my kids scattered.

Definitely nothing suspicious going on here.

I'm going to bed.

12-year-old: Why are we having leftovers again?

Me: We have to eat them.

12: It's okay to give up.

10-year-old: *playing with her sisters* We're having so much fun!

Me: It sounds like you're killing each other.

10: Fun is loud.

Me: How did babysitting your sisters go?

12-year-old: Good.

Me: Are they all still in one piece?

12: How should I know? You don't pay me.

I definitely shouldn't have tried to make that sound. Worst wookiee impression ever.
https://t.co/r0QLeH9z8e

Me: I have three chores for you to do today.

8-year-old: I can do two.

Me: This isn't a negotiation.

8: I can do one.

6-year-old: There's nothing to do.

Me: Come here and do chores.

6: There are lots of things I could play with.

Those are some incredibly embarrassing family stories. I probably shouldn't be sharing them on the internet.
https://t.co/r0QLeH9z8e

12-year-old: Why don't they ever throw chocolate at parades?

Me: It would melt.

12: Liquid chocolate is still good.

6-year-old: *licks a sucker and rolls it in pop rocks*

Me: What are you doing?

6: Magic.

Me: Do you want to go see the fireworks tonight?

8-year-old: Only if they're quiet.

Keep it down, guys.

Me: What are you doing?

10-year-old: Eating all the snacks.

Me: I literally said DON’T eat all the snacks.

10: Oh. I missed that word.

Because of the holiday weekend, I'm pushing this week's newsletter to Tuesday. In the meantime, you can tide yourself over with the most recent issue. In terms of repair costs, it was easily our most expensive series of disasters ever.
https://t.co/OOBRSl4RQK
My 8-year-old got out of bed and then changed her mind. Nice try, Sunday. https://t.co/CxKaTJCIBC

Me: I saw a bald eagle on the Fourth of July! That's 12 more months of freedom.

Wife: It's not the Fourth of July.

Me: Why do you hate America?

[driving through downtown Minneapolis]

6-year-old: Is that the Eiffel Tower?!

Me: Yes. Yes, it is.

8-year-old: This guy in front of me was going so slow.

Me: Was he old?

8: Really old. Like, your age.

Wife: Want to hear an interesting fact about mushrooms?

Me: *looks up from an extremely important project on deadline* Yes.

Me: Have you packed?

8-year-old: For what?

Me: The trip I've been talking about all week.

8: I forgot to listen.

10-year-old: Dad?

Me: Yeah?

10: Isn't it weird that people have faces?

Being 10 is a lot like being high.

[working through my to-do list]

Me: Man, I'm exhausted.

Wife: How many things did you get done?

Me: Zero.

Me: Stop fighting with your sister.

8-year-old: Okay. *keeps fighting*

Me: I told you to stop.

8: It will be over when I win.

They say there are no bad days on the water. I proved that wrong.
https://t.co/OOBRSl5pGi

10-year-old: Oh. You got a new haircut.

Me: Does it look worse?

10: No. Just equally bad.

She wants the title of my craziest child. Did she earn it?
https://t.co/coyQBvysWm
My 12-year-old made this for me from scratch. People keep warning me about the teenage years. I'm assuming I'm supposed to watch out for larger and more dangerous cakes. https://t.co/oWP7x3Ed37

My wife was alone in the bathroom at work when the lights flickered.

She nearly had a heart attack.

No more watching "Stranger Things" at night.

Kids at powerful engines don't mix. Especially on the water.
https://t.co/djSqmP8pyS

8-year-old: Are we doing anything today?

Me: No.

8: *breathes a huge sigh of relief*

8-year-old: *drops a ceramic bowl, shattering it*

Me: What happened?

8: The floor.
Nothing makes me feel more special on my birthday than a spam email from every company I've ever bought something from to remind me they all have my personal information.

8-year-old: *makes a blanket fort*

Me: How can you do that when you claim you can't make your bed?

8: They're different skills.
My next newsletter tomorrow, but you can still catch up on last week's. My kids are becoming more dangerous by the hour: https://t.co/JZ23Gt9JuQ

10-year-old: *panics over something minor*

Me: You don't have to freak out.

10: I do. It's the only way.

6-year-old: I'm having fun!

Me: Are you breaking something?

6: No.

Me: Are you sure?

6: Everything is already broke.

8-year-old: We need to talk.

Me: About what?

8: Mario Kart.

It just got real.

Me: Are you ready to go?

10-year-old: We need to pack car snacks.

Me: The drive isn't even an hour.

10: We need to pack car snacks.

8-year-old: *runs through the house scream singing*

Me: Do you have to do that?

8: No. That's why it's fun.

12-year-old: It's National Eat All The Chicken Nuggets Day.

Me: That's not a thing.

12: It's a thing if you buy us all the chicken nuggets.

8-year-old: Can I have my own phone?

Me: No. You'll mostly just use it to play around.

8: What do you use yours for?

Touché.

12-year-old: I cleaned my room.

Me: Did you actually clean up the mess, or did you just move it?

12-year-old: Technically, all cleaning is just moving a mess.

She's right and I don't like it.

Neither of us should be trusted on the open water.
https://t.co/xq26GeGGfM

Me: You can't stay home by yourself.

8-year-old: You can trust me, Dad. I'm responsible.

Me: You're holding nunchucks.

8: I'm holding nunchucks responsibly.

10-year-old: Why do we have to dust?

Me: If we don't, there will be more spiders.

10: *dusts vigorously*

6-year-old: Can we go to the pool?

Me: Not right now.

6: You never take us!

Me: I took you yesterday.

6: That was so long ago I forgot.

Me: Are you watching this TV?

8-year-old: No.

Me: Then turn it off.

8: But then somebody else will take it.

On second thought, I wish my kids were a little less ready for anything.
https://t.co/JZ23Gt9JuQ

I realized today that I've been doing the math wrong and I'm actually a year younger than I've been telling people.

I'm still a million years old, but whatever.

I'm aging backwards.

12-year-old: Where are you going?

Me: To exercise.

12: On purpose?

Thanks for the vote of confidence.

We were driving home when "Bohemian Rapsody" came on the radio.

What the song said: Monstrosity.

What my 8-year-old heard: Warm sausage tea.

The lyrics have been updated to her version for all future car singalongs.

10-year-old: Why don't we ever buy fireworks?

Me: They're a waste of money.

10: Nothing that explodes is a waste of money.

WARNING: My children are now even more dangerous.
https://t.co/JZ23Gt9JuQ

Me: How many doughnuts did you have?

8-year-old: The right number.

Me: How many was that?

8: All of them.

Me: *mixing different alcohols together*

Wife: What are you making?

Me: A mistake.

An all new newsletter comes out tomorrow, but in the meantime, you can still read about last week's (mis)adventure. My daughter may never forgive me.
https://t.co/WXeuIK27Jj

12-year-old: I've done a lot today.

Me: All you did was watch YouTube.

12: But I watched a lot of it.
RT @James_Breakwell : https://t.co/Doc2R8Wc6q
WARNING: Photo may include dangerous levels of cool. https://t.co/RHYSCkMuY9
Tell me you're visiting Wisconsin without telling me you're visiting Wisconsin. https://t.co/rnPOoFXrZ8

My 10-year-old was distraught.

We visited a house with three dogs, but she only has two hands.

Someone would have to wait to be pet.

Then she started petting the third dog with her foot.

My 6-year-old, unfolding herself after sleeping like a human pretzel in the car: Let's run!

Me, standing up after driving for an hour: I am literally going to die.

10-year-old: I'm wearing heels.

Me: Oh.

10: I shouldn't be trusted with this much power.

If I had a house without running water, I'd move. Not this guy.
https://t.co/vmWL7fMu7M
My 10-year-old wanted me to tell everyone that she found a really, really big strawberry. We've reached peak excitement at my house. https://t.co/gyY193k3FL

I have many talents. This is not one of them.
https://t.co/pNVgNkmdHK

Me: Here's your list of chores for today.

12-year-old: But I just did chores yesterday.

Me: There are chores to do every day.

12: Real life is impossible.

10-year-old: *fights with her sister over what to watch*

Me: Go watch the other TV.

10: Someone's watching it.

Me: Then go watch the other other TV.

10: I don't want to walk that far.

6-year-old: Why does the kitchen look weird?

Me: It's clean.

6: I don't like it.

I took my kids to the pool for the first time this season.

I figured they'd wear themselves out in an hour.

Instead, we're on hour three, and they're still going strong, while I need a nap.

Maybe they can carry me home.

Be honest, am I a monster for bringing my kid into this?
https://t.co/d5eZ4PROgK
My 12-year-old told me her favorite Star Wars movie is Episode I, and now I have to spend the rest of the afternoon looking up how to cut someone out of my will.

I found my 6-year-old with a shot glass.

I asked what she was using it for.

She said Mountain Dew.

It would have been safer if she said vodka.

Me: Don't make bad choices.

10-year-old: But I'm so good at them.

8-year-old: Can we go to the park?

Me: It's raining.

8: That will just make the slides faster.

And that's why I'll be limping for the rest of the week.
https://t.co/d5eZ4PROgK

I overheard my 8-year-old ask another kid, "Do you think my dad is buff?"

I swelled with pride until the other kid said no.

That's what I get for eavesdropping.
In case you were on the fence about getting your kids bunk beds, I just had to scrub footprints off the ceiling.

[in the van]

6-year-old: Why did you stop?

Me: There's a red light.

6: It's not the boss of you.

My new newsletter comes out tomorrow, but it's not to late to read the one from last week. Hopefully we never have that much "fun" again.
https://t.co/DTTwS84PeU

My 8-year-old correctly used the word "aesthetic" in a sentence.

When I asked her where she learned it, she said YouTube.

That site is ruining her life. It's turning her into an English major.

10-year-old: There were two President Bushes?!

Me: One was before you were born.

Wife: Both were before she was born.

I am a million years old.

8-year-old: Can you buy me a snow cone?

Me: No. We have a good blender. We can make snow cones at home.

8: But do we have a mystery flavor?

Me: Yes. If I don't tell you what it is.

8-year-old: I found a one-leaf clover.

Me: Why does it have one leaf?

8: It had really bad luck.

8-year-old: I figured out the best ice cream flavor.

Me: What?

8: Whatever you let me eat the most of.

Based on the amount of hate mail I'm getting this week, there are quite a few people who haven't read this yet. Feel free to skip ahead to the second part.
https://t.co/NjGsb28NC3
Weird how my kids make up games with a million different rules but they all basically boil down to "yell as loudly as possible and break things."

Instead of a good night kiss, my 8-year-old gave me a good night fist bump.

I'm not sure if I leveled up or down as a parent.

8-year-old: I got to ride in the back of a police car!

Me: Were you in trouble?

8: No. I'll never get caught.

That's how I learned that planning too much is even worse than not planning at all.
https://t.co/y1IELKQ3QF

My 6-year-old said when she grows up she wants to be a "chainsaw guy." 

Not sure if she means a professional tree trimmer like the ones working across the street or a serial killer in a hockey mask, but girls can do it all.

My 6-year-old just walked up to me out of the blue and told me she's not  up to anything.

Now I have to watch her like a hawk.

[telling me about scout camp]

8-year-old: I touched a fish!

Me: What did it feel like?

8: A fish.

Mind. Blown.

Me: Where are your shoes?

6-year-old: Off.

Me: Off where?

6: Off for the summer.

And that's why we're never getting invited to a wedding again.
https://t.co/DTTwS84PeU

8-year-old: I have a problem.

Me: What?

8: I have too many friends.

Can't relate.

Me: Stop stomping.

10-year-old: I'm not. I'm walking with power.

So this is the adventure we just went through.
https://t.co/DTTwS84PeU

After doing a load of my kids' laundry, I found Christmas tree tinsel in the washing machine.

In June.

Whatever. I just threw in another load.

I spent forty minutes waiting for an order of fancy gormet hotdogs for my kids.

The bad news is my kids hated them.

That's also the good news.

I just ate five hot dogs.

I'm frantically working to finish the newsletter for tomorrow, but it's not too late to read the one from last Monday. It's the only real parenting advice I've ever given. It's not for everybody, but trust me: It always works.
https://t.co/rB0BpS9YJI
Waffle yesterday on the five minute drive from the church to the reception. Weddings are exhausting. https://t.co/MH2j0jHk89

My wife: *inspecting her makeup* I should have used more concealer around my mouth.

12-year-old: I'm pretty sure they're they're going to know you have a mouth.
Killing time before the wedding. If playing nerdy board games in fancy dresses is wrong, I don't want to be right. https://t.co/cYxqfDydpa
I'm not sure what stage of wedding prep we're at, but my wife just asked me to move lamps around this Airbnb to get the lighting for her makeup right, so I think we're officially in crisis mode.

My 6-year-old lost a tooth at the rehearsal dinner. And I do mean "lost." The tooth disappeared on the restaurant floor until a waitress found it. Hopefully that tooth fairy money will cover an extra big tip. https://t.co/BUYgiHvPYV
@brassnevich1910 I share your confusion. I have no idea what happened.
Watch out, St. Louis. The Breakwell women are out on the town. https://t.co/V9pTEQRAQv

[driving to a wedding]

Wife: I forgot the bra I need for all my dresses this weekend!

Me: Couldn't you just not wear one?

Wife: *death glare*

Me: *turns the van around*

[kids yelling]

Me: Stop fighting.

12-year-old: We're not.

Me: What do you call this?

12: Getting ready to fight.

I ruined my children's favorite toy. It's a wonder people don't ask me to review more stuff.
https://t.co/sfvTOIZA6M

My 7-year-old never asked me to teach her to ride a bike or tie her shoes, but today, she asked me to teach her to cook bacon.

She's got her priorities straight. https://t.co/DWiFVNN3lR

7-year-old: *dumps her toy dinosaurs all over the floor*

Me: You can't just leave your dinosaurs everywhere.

7-year-old: It was their planet first.

7-year-old: *hands me a toy sword*

Me: What's this for?

7: Just hold it for me for a while.

I think she's hiding evidence.

6-year-old: *points to sister* She hit me!

Me: Why?

6: I hit her.

I consider this matter closed.

10-year-old: I cleaned off my whole desk yesterday.

Me: Why is it a mess again?

10: I used it for a whole day since then.

My kids were fighting, so I made them separate.

Then they begged me to let them play together.

You are Edubot, one of the characters in “The Chosen Twelve,” coming out in just twelve days. Half the kids see you as the enemy, but are you really? Decide for yourself. Read the book to hear Edubot’s story and learn the fate of her twenty-two ungrateful charges.

Do you love the kids? No. But do you protect them? Sort of. Only, like, two of them die on your watch, which is a pretty good survival rate if you really think about it. Until everything goes wrong and a war breaks out, but that’s another story.

Regardless of how you got here, there’s no quitting now. You have to raise and educate the last twenty-two humans in existence by yourself. If you fail, all intelligent life dies out forever. No pressure.

This wasn’t supposed to be your job. You’re not really the nurturing sort. Instead of arms to hug, you have gleaming metal talons. Instead of legs, you have tank treads. You’re a mining bot, built for crushing ore. Tucking in the kids for bed is a challenge.

Now imagine that you live in a place where everything is trying to kill them. Moving to a better neighborhood isn’t an option. Oh, and you have to homeschool, which is a treat, because when the kids aren’t almost getting themselves killed, they’re full of attitude. Jerks.

Raising a kid on your own is hard enough, but imagine that you have more than one. Way more. Like, twenty-two. Somehow, they’re all twelve years old, which means they want to be independent, but they’re also super incompetent and will totally die if you leave them alone.
There’s a single parent out there who gets a bad rap, but I want to take a moment to defend her.

Well, anything that I wrote. If you order Harry Potter, I probably won’t sign that. Unless you really want me to.

My friend Tamzin, who owns the store, ordered a big stockpile of the books, which I’ll be signing in the next few days. That stockpile includes many of my prior books, so anything you order from her will have my signature in it.

So now what? If you got a cancelation notice, please pre-order again. The book is still coming out. If the original retailer you selected won’t let you place a new pre-order, you can always order from Main Street Books in Lafayette, Indiana.

Without pre-orders, my writing career is dead in the water. And now, after a year of writing this book and months of doing everything in my power to entice you to pre-order it, I could very well be back at square one. Happy Thursday.

How many pre-orders did I lose? No idea, but it could be anywhere from just a few to literally all of them. This is a nightmare scenario. As an author, I depend on pre-orders to ensure the success of this book and to land future book deals. That’s why I promote it so hard.

Those retailers then notified you that you can no longer get my book, which you actually can. In fact, some of the very same retailers that sent out the cancelation email still list my book for sale and are allowing those sales to go through. Strange times, and not in a good way.

So what caused this train wreck? My publisher, Benbella Books, is changing distributors, the middle man between publishers and retailers. Rather than allowing for a smooth transition, the old distributor contacted retailers and basically said, “All Benbella books are canceled.”

Actually, it’s coming out ahead of schedule. We removed the embargo date, so retailers are allowed to ship it out as soon as they have it on hand. Instead of waiting until June 1, some of you might be receiving it any day now. Assuming your pre-order wasn’t erroneously canceled.
“How To Be A Man (Whatever That Means): Lessons in Modern Masculinity From A Questionable Source” is still coming out June 1, as scheduled.

Let me start off by saying my book is NOT Canceled.

Some (Many? All?) of you may have received an email from your retailer of choice that your pre-order has been canceled because my publisher canceled the book. This is absolutely wrong.
Brace yourself. This is my first ever Twitter thread. What kind of epic disaster made this necessary? Well…
